He explained the two criteria : The deceased veterans had to be registered at ASU as a student , according to the university 's records department , and they had to have died while on active duty serving in the U.S. military .
Private First Class Tony Pearl Roomsburg was among nearly 20 Women 's Army Corps ( WAC ) members on an Army Air Force transport plane that crashed in Africa , killing everyone on board .
A native Arizonan , Roomsburg graduated from Arizona State Teachers ' College in 1942 to become an elementary school teacher .
She had enlisted as a WAC when tragedy struck in 1945 , making her one of the first female overseas casualties of the war .

RelatedSentence: Professor Mark von Hagen , director for ASU 's new Office of Veteran and Military Academic Engagement , said sharing the stories of all ASU student veterans is important .

Von Hagen serves on the faculties of global studies in the School of Politics and Global Studies and history in the School of Historical , Philosophical and Religious Studies in the College of Liberal Arts and Sciences .
As a historian , von Hagen works with students to capture oral histories of living veterans from America 's most recent conflicts .

For today 's student veterans , the In Memoriam commemoration of ASU alumni who served their country and never came home underscores the military lineage of the university , said Steven Borden , director of ASU 's Pat Tillman Veterans Center and retired U.S. Navy Captain .
ASU first honored its veterans when it dedicated its iconic Memorial Union on the Tempe campus in 1956 .
